required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: A Phase 2 Study To Assess The Efficacy, Tolerability, And Safety OF NKTR-181 In Subjects With Chronic OA Knee Pain
clinical_study.official_title: A Phase 2, Enriched-Enrollment, Randomized-Withdrawal, Double-Blind, Placebo-Controlled, Multi-Center Study to Assess the Efficacy, Tolerability, and Safety of NKTR-181 in Opioid-Naïve Subjects With Moderate to Severe Chronic Pain Due to Osteoarthritis of the Knee

brief_summary.textblock: NKTR-181 is being developed as an analgesic compound for the treatment of moderate to severe chronic pain - active as a mu agonist, but with inherent molecular properties designed to provide a unique clinical profile, including most notably, reduced CNS side effects and an attenuated attractiveness as a target of abuse.

study_design_info.masking: Quadruple (Participant, Care Provider, Investigator, Outcomes Assessor)

primary_outcome.measure: The Mean Change From Baseline Pain Score to Pain Score at the End of the Double-blind Randomized Treatment Period.
primary_outcome.description: The first phase of this trial involved an open-label titration period where patients were given NKTR-181 at increasing doses up to a maximum of 400 mg twice daily until adequate pain control was achieved. Patients achieving adequate pain control were then progressed to the second phase of the trial where patients were randomized in a 1:1 ratio to receive either placebo or their tolerable dose level of NKTR-181. All efficacy data for NKTR-181 patients was combined into one group regardless of tolerable dose level. For this outcome, the subjects had to rate their worst pain intensity during the past 4 hours from 0 to 10 on an 11-point scale, where 0 represented one end of the continuum (i.e., no pain) and 10 represented the other extreme of pain intensity (i.e., worst pain imaginable).

secondary_outcome.measure: Time to Discontinuation During the Double-blind Randomized Treatment Period for Any Reason
secondary_outcome.description: The first phase of this trial involved an open-label titration period where patients were given NKTR-181 at increasing doses up to a maximum of 400 mg twice daily until adequate pain control was achieved. Patients achieving adequate pain control were then progressed to the second phase of the trial where patients were randomized in a 1:1 ratio to receive either placebo or their tolerable dose level of NKTR-181. All efficacy data for NKTR-181 patients was combined into one group regardless of tolerable dose level.

arm_group.description: 100 mg of NKTR-181 in tablet form, BID. Dosing to occur at Titration period up to 30 days and at Randomization period up to 24 days.
200 mg of NKTR-181 in tablet form, BID. Dosing to occur at Titration period up to 30 days and at Randomization period up to 24 days.
300 mg of NKTR-181 in tablet form, BID. Dosing to occur at Titration period up to 30 days and at Randomization period up to 24 days
400 mg of NKTR-181 in tablet form, BID. Dosing to occur at Titration period up to 30 days and at Randomization period up to 24 days
Placebo dosing will be only in the double-blind randomization arm and will be identical in form to the Experimental NKTR-181.

intervention.description: Placebo dosing will be only in the double-blind randomization arm and will be identical in form to the Experimental NKTR-181

participant_flow.pre_assignment_details: A total of 296 subjects were enrolled in this study. Of these, one subject did not receive study drug in the open-label Titration Period because she had a history of drug abuse and thus did not meet entry criteria. Of the 295 subjects dosed during the open-label Titration Period, 213 subjects were randomized to treatment. All 295 subjects who received study drug were included in the safety analysis population.

reported_events.desc: Please note that the number of participants at risk analyzed for Serious Adverse Events includes all patients that were enrolled in the study not just the ones that were randomized to treatment.
